- jb - Sorry to hear you are having earthquakes in Oklahoma.
But really, about subject of Common Core - what are your objections? How can your state object to the math standards? Is arithmetic really different there than in CA?
And the English standards are pretty normal too. We all want our kids to be able to read and think and discuss and defend their opinions. So which standards (exactly) do you and others in Oklahoma not like? I'd love to see a specific standard that you think should be revised.
Not sure, why everything needs to be tied to "Civil Liberties"? Opposition for opposition's sake lose its purpose.

It never ceases to amaze me how effective fear mongering can be. I sure hope that Jeb Bush and other Republican governors hold their ground in calling out the paranoid far right. But the paranoia seems to catch on like wildfire, and the next thing you know, plans for a healthy and educated populace are a socialist plot. It is so very sad.

Benchmarks don't work because too many students can't meet the standards. This upsets parents (My child, behind? Impossible!), kids (I'm not special?), teachers (Me? Incompetent?) and administrators (But how do we force half the kids to repeat the grade?). It's just so much easier to lower the bar and promote all the illiterates and innumerates out of the system. Rubber-stamp the report cards with high grades and everybody's happy.

rimantes - the US has only had standards for 15 years - and they have actually worked very well. Score have been going up in all states - and the biggest gains have been in the states that have the best standards. With Common Core we are now just giving every state a chance to have standards like the ones that work best for US kids and also international kids that they will have to compete with around the world.
http://nces.ed.gov/nationsreportcard/states/

Looks like your state of Md is doing quite - well. You are way above the national average and your students have made huge gains since state standards started 15 years ago. Congratulations to your state, your students and your wonderful teachers.

@Douglas:
The statistics our local papers display to prove that on this or that occasion the scores went up cannot be believed. As with all statistics, they can be juggled to mean what you want them to mean, and as with all statistics they up and down. And it's in the interest of bureaucrats and politicians to make these scores look good.

Why can't the educational establishment face the fact that "learning benchmarks, intended to raise students' proficiency in math and English" just don't work?? Various schemes have been tried in the last decades, including the disastrous New Math, and none succeeded raising student's proficiency. The local papers in big cites run stories regularly how behind their school are in educating children.

And recently, when some parents wanted to challenge Common Core in open meetings, they were silenced and in one local case the police was called on them. It seems the education elite don't know how to educate, hire more and more people to cook up more and more studies to propose more and more approaches to teaching, all requiring more and more taxpayers' money, and when those things don't work, they try to force it.

Why would anyone thus be surprised that parents are rejecting Common Core? Being for or against Obama has nothing to do with it; rather, protecting children from the entrenched bureaucrats.

Except for the critique of capital, there's nothing common between Marx and Thomas Piketty. For, offering a holistic alternative materialistic perspective of human liberation while Marx views capitalism as degeneration of human predicament, Piketty is all for capitalism and market economy, fairer than what exists today though. It's thus the ascendancy of financial capitalism over industrial capitalism, that has created vast income and wealth disparity between the top 0.01% capital owners and the rest, largely the wage earners, small business owners and salaried professional middle class. It's to this disproportionate income and wealth advantage of the rentier class derived through investment and interest income over the work wages by the working class that Piketty draws attention to, advancing a plea to reform the capitalism, not to overthrow it through revolution as Marx would have it.
Common Core, contrary to what Republicans like to project, is a set of standards adopted by states. It is not mandated by "Washington DC".

Yes, very controlling. And in the process of exerting this control, the teachers are loaded with more and more with tasks other than direct teaching of children. Obviously, first in line to suffer are the little kids.

And what's the use of being "in tune with what top colletes desire" if the high school seniors fail to graduate?

Actually, it's the left who doesn't want an educated public, because such public will be more and more dependent on the government. And the more people are dependent on big government, the more motivated they are to vote the party who made it so big.

James Horn is on target. There are sincere, deep, and valid concerns about the whole CC enterprise. It's one step closer to the total outsourcing of American education. Teachers are losing control of the curriculum and the evaluation. Both are imposed from outside, by a corporation making a profit. The teachers are not even allowed to see "behind the curtain" of the testing to see where they went wrong. It is, as James Horn says, a corporate takeover.

Ask your kids: the tests are a joke. The kids know that. The teachers know that. And yet both are forced to teach and learn to the tests. This is the story whenever and wherever there is a corporate takeover of education. The AP courses and tests are a good example. They are designed for students who just devour material. Students who want to really delve into a subject and actually learn some nuances, or maybe explore it in depth to see if a lifetime interest develops are out of luck.

What disturbs many parents and teachers is not the loss of liberty, per se, but the imposition of lockstep curriculum development, lockstep pacing, lockstep testing. Administrators love it because it's easy. The "hard part" of their job, the truly creative part, is done for them. It's trendy so no one is going to call them on it. Meanwhile, the corporate cookie cutter is applied to our kids, lopping off the edges that stick out, the edges that make them who and what they are...or might be.

I had just turned 17. Two friends and I decided to play hooky and attend the opening day of the Fair. We came in on the 7 train from the Port Authority Bus Terminal. We were expecting excitement and chaos from all the threatened civil rights demonstrations.
Most of the fair was still under construction, and there seemed to be as many white construction workers as fair attendees. We went to the Schaefer Beer center to try to get served. We were. There was a civil rights demonstration underway, and the construction workers, drinking beer, were attempting to pick fights with the demonstrators. The demonstrators were very restrained. There were lots of news photographers around, and I was afraid I would be in the newspaper holding a Schaefer beer. Later we had lunch at Chung King, and a waitress dressed to look Chinese dumped an entire meal in a businessman's fedora. I was looking around for Allen Funt. It seemed that every third world country had a truck tire on display, to show how advanced their industry was. Later, at the Brass Rail, we had free dinner, because there was nobody at the end of the cafeteria line manning the cash register. I also remember the IBM "people wall", an almost vertical grandstand that hydraulically raised you into an egg shaped theater. As it started to move up, one of my friends shouted "I'm going to throw up" and the people below and in front of him grew very concerned.
All in all, a much better day than one spent in class.

But more to the point, if Common Core is such a wonderful idea why is there no study of any kind showing its superiority to any current state-run program? Why does the federal government feel the need to offer financial incentives if states adopt the program?

Republicans go on and on about the lazy undereducated poor, and then on and on about a mostly imaginary "skills gap," and then on and on about efforts to improve educational expectations. Sigh.

And yes, I know the issue they prefer to highlight is the legitimacy of federal action on education, saying each state, district, household should have the ultimate say in what is taught to kids, but if you follow that logic to its conclusion, then clearly their vision for the USA is one that leads to total dissolution along cultural, wealth, and religious lines. The Red states will break into splintered fiefdoms with vastly unequal levels of educational attainment and stark cultural and wealth divisions between the peasantry and the hereditary Church-State complex. The self-appointed nobility will distract itself with seasonal raids against neighbors and occasionally its own peasantry, and enjoy its elaborate and insular displays of wealth, reviving the courtly ideals of feminine modesty and violence equated with honor. The Church will be fully revived and de facto brought into governance, preaching a dogma of divine right for the already privileged, and myths of equality before god and in death.

Several of the kids note their fear of “zombies. “ There’s been a massive marketing effort underway for years by the gun and ammo industry to attract new young shooters as well as doomsday preppers via the notion of a pending “zombie apocalypse.” Gun ranges offer zombie-themed targets and ammunition. Several prominent firearms-related TV shows feature entire segments showing teams of shooters eliminating hordes of “zombie” targets. Though most of these efforts are presented as tongue-in-cheek, it’s not much of a stretch to realize the fears being played on are fears of the “other.” When the supposed hordes go on a rampage, they won’t be zombies, but the white, black, brown, yellow, or rainbow colored folks the gun lobby is trying to set us up to fear. These marketing tactics are irresponsible and shameful. Full disclosure: I’m a liberal gun owner.
